biography: British author best known for writing the Harry Potter fantasy series, which has won multiple awards and sold more than 500 million copies worldwide.
English novelist, essayist, journalist and critic whose work is marked by lucid prose, awareness of social injustice, and fierce opposition to totalitarianism.
American novelist widely known for her novel To Kill a Mockingbird, published in 1960, which won the 1961 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction.
English writer known for her sixty-six detective novels and fourteen short story collections, particularly those revolving around fictional detectives Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple.
American author of horror, supernatural fiction, suspense, crime, science-fiction, and fantasy novels.
English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique and comment upon the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century.
American novelist, short-story writer, and journalist whose economical and understated style had a strong influence on 20th-century fiction.
Colombian novelist, short-story writer, screenwriter, and journalist, known affectionately as Gabo throughout Latin America.
